title: Is it usually easy for you to see both sides of an argument? If so, how? If not, why? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, I easily see both sides of an argument. BTW, Aristotle was famous for that. Often he explained the other side of an argument better than the opponent could! How can one get better at seeing both sides? Let’s concentrate on arguments where you favor one side, but want to understand your opponent better. First, read good thinkers like Aristotle, to see how it’s done.Suspend judgment while reading the other side. You may hate their premises, but ignore that. Don’t let it interfere with following their logic. Often, BTW, they’re not being logical; do your best to make sense of it anyway. Give them maximum benefit of the doubt while reading.With most important issues, there are millions of people on each side. They can’t all be crazy and stupid! The other guy’s view must make sense, even though ultimately it’s wrong. If you firmly believe that, it makes finding that sense a lot easier.If you can talk with them, don’t try to convince them they’re wrong. That’s almost always impossible anyway. Suppress your disgust and disagreement. Instead ask sympathetic, non-judgmental questions, and you’ll get useful information. Later on you can tell them exactly what you think of them :-)Humans are all fundamentally the same. If someone believes proposition X, then so would you, in their circumstances. Usually there’s really only one way to make sense of someone’s ‘wrong’ view. For example, suppose people think it’s ok to torture animals. How can this be? Clearly, they must not realize animals feel, just like we do. I mean, just one person might be a psychopathic sadist, but not millions. There has to be a logical reason; it can only be that they see animals as objects: chairs or tables. Probably because they’ve never gotten to know any animals. See how easy it is? No matter how disgusting or weird an opinion might be, there’s always some way to make sense of it. If you were in their situation, you’d have the same ‘stupid’ opinion. If you firmly believe that, you’ll find it a lot easier to put yourself in their place.

It becomes easier if you practise. But go further. Here’s a discipline I’ve found incredibly useful. Practise using your brains and imagination to consider at least 4-6 sides to every argument. Take apart the data and the narrative as suggested (beautifully) earlier by Paul Shunamon. We always have a choice and and we can make better decisions and better choices if we have alternatives to choose from. Insist on alternatives. Push yourself to create 4-6 reasonable alternatives, then you can make good choice. “I didn’t have any choice” is the single most popular rationale on the planet for doing stupid, vicious, hateful and destructive things. We always have a choice. That’s “responsibility” and you can exercise, practise and develop “responsibility” by developing alternatives to choose from.
